ALSO it is ordained and agreed, that if any of the King's liege-man or officer of his land of Ireland be out of the faid land of Ireland by the commandment of the King or his heirs, lieutenants, their deputies, juftices, or the King’s council in Ireland, that all their lands, tenements, rents, benefices, or offices, or other pofTeffipn* whatfoever, by their faid abfency shall not be feifed nor taken into the Kang’s hands, or his heirs, nor their offices void. And if it fo fortune, that any of the faid officers be taken by pyrates, or any other ill doers or enemies, that they at their return may occupy their faid offices, notwithstanding any grant or gift of the faid offices made to any other perfon in their abfence. And if any leifin or gift be made to the contrary, the fame shall be void and holden for none.

Highways to be made on the perfon's own land who will make it.

All indi&-ments, to the contrary of thi* flatute, void.

This flatute to beobferved within fran-chifes.

The thirty -/eventb Tear of Henry the Sixth. land. The premifes therefore confidered, it is ordained and eftablifhed by the authority of the faid Parliament, That it shall be lawful to every tenant and inhabitant of fuch towns and villages being in high-wayes for to flop, ditch, and inclofe the faid towns and villages in the flrongeft manner that they can, fo as there shall be a competent and a fufficient high-way left and made for carts and carriages through or near the faid towns or villages, fo that people be not interrupted in their paflage from market to market, nor that the high-wayes be not made very far about, not above forty perches. Provided always, that any man, that will make an high-way, {hall make the fame upon his own land. And that the tenants and inhabitants of fuch towns and villages may lawfully flop, ditch in, and inclofe fuch towns and villages in form aforefaid without any impeachment of our lovereign lord the King, his heirs, or mir.ifters, in time to come ; And if any office, feifure, or indi&ment be hereafter found contrary to this flatute again ft any perfon or perfons, it shall be adjudged void, and of no value nor effcift. And this flatute fhall be obferved and take place as well within franchises and liberties as without, and as well againft lords of franchifes, their minifters and officers, as agairll the King.

The Thirty-feventh Year of HENRY VI.

An A El that Warrants made to the great Seal Jhall have the Day of their Delivery to the Chancellory &c. entred. and that the Patents Jhall bear the Date of that Day. Rot. Pari. cap. 13.

AT the requefl of the commons, for that, that the lieutenant of our fovereign lord the King of Ireland, or their deputies, juftices, and other governours of the faid land, at the fpecial requeft of diverfe gentlemen have made their warrants to be diredled into the chancery of Ireland of lands, tenements, rents, offices, and fervices, to bear date long time before divers other warrants, directed into the faid chancery, of the faid lands, tenements, rents, offices, and fervices, whereby divers the King’s liege-people, having fuch lands, tenements, rents, offices, and Cervices, of the gift or grant of the King by the faid warrants, have been put out of their faid lands, tenements, rents, offices, and Cervices, granted by our fovereign lord the King, by force of the faid antedates againil reafon, right, and confcience : Wherefore to do away fuch fubtile imaginations of fuch antedates it is ordained and eftablifhed by authority of the faid Parliament, that upon every warrant hereafter by the King’s juftices of Ireland, the King’s lieutenant of lrclAnd, or their deputy there for the time

being,

II

*Ybe third and eighth Years of Edward the Fourth• being, to be addrefled to the chancellor of Ireland, or his deputy there, or keeper of the great feal of Ireland, for the time being, the day of the delivery to the laid chancellor, deputy, or keeper, lhall be entrrd of record in the faid chancery, and that the King’s letters patents be made upon the fame warrants, bearing date the day of the fame delivery into the faid chancery, and not before in any manner. And if any letters patents of onr fovereign lord the King be made to the contrary, they shall be void, and holden for none, to begin the firft day of March next coming, and from thenceforward.

CHAP. IX.

An Aft againft lading Wools and Flocks•

ITEM, prayen the commons. That whereas taking aid lading of wool and flockes out of this land hath bees the caufe of dearth of cloth, and idlenefle of many folkes; fo that in default of labour and occupation of the lame divers perfons. both men and women, have fain to theft and other mifgovernance to the defolation and ruine of this poor land, as it doth daily appear by experience ; Therefore bd it ena&ed by the authority of this prefent Parliament, That noperfon ne perfons from henceforth iade ne take out of this land any wooll or flockes upon pain of forfeiture of the double value of the fame, the one half unto the King, and the other half to him that will fue therefore ; and that it b6 lawfull to every man to fue for the fame as well by aCtiop of debt, as by information, in any of the King’s courts; in which a&ion of debt the partie or parties defendants shall have none effoine, protection, lie law wager : and that it be lawful unto all the King’s juftices of peace* that hereafter shall be made, to enquire of the premiEes.

CHAP. VII.

An Act of Slaunder. Rot. Parl. cap. 8.

[26 H. 8. 13. Eng.
Slandering the King, Queen, or heirs aparent, or detaining any of the King's fortresses, &c. treason]

WHERE in a Parliament begun at London in the realm of England, the third day of November, the xxi. year of the raign of our most dread soveraign lord King Henry 
the eighth, King of England and of France, defen-rent, or detain- dor of the faith. Lord of Ireland, and fupream head in ing any of the earth of the church of England, and from thence adjoum-KmgMortreffes, ecj to Weftminfter, and by divers prorogations there holden *c. trea on. ancj continued, it was and is enaded amongft other things, in manner and form as followeth: Forafmach as it is raoft necefiary, boih for common policie and dutie of fubjeds, above all things, to prohibit, provide, reftrain, and extind all manner of (hameful (launders, perills, or iminent danger or dangers which might grow, happen or rife to their sovereign

Lord the King, the Queen and their heyers, which when	A. D.

they be heard, feen, or underftood, cannot be but odibie,	1537-

iftbje&s, if in any point they may doe or fhall touch the King, hii Qtjeen, their hey res and fucceflors, upon which dependeth the whole unitie, and the univerfali weal of this realm, without providing wherefore too great a flop of un-reafonable libertie fhould be given to all cankred and tray-* tfcrous hearts, workers and willera of the fame, and alfo the King’s loving fubjefts fhould not declare unto their fove-raign Lord now being (which unto them hath been, and is moft entirely both beloved and efteemed) their undoubted fincerity and truth. Be it therefore enafted by the aflent and confent of our foveraign Lord the King, and the lords fpiritual and temporal, and the commons in this prefent Parliament affembled, and by authority of the fame. That if any perfon or perfons, after the firft day of February next coming, doe maliciouily wifh, will, or defire, by words, or writing, or by craft, imagin, invent, pra&ife, or attempt, any bodily harm to be done or committed to the King’s moil royal perfon, the Queen, or their heyres apparent, or to deprive them, or any of them, of the dignitie, title, or name of their royal eftates, or flaunderoufly and maliciouily publifh and pronounce by exprefs writing, or words, that the King our foveraign lord fhould be heretick, fchifmatick, tyrant, infidell, or uiurperof the crown, or re-bcllioufly doth detain, keep, or withhold from our faid foveraign Lord, his heyers or fucceflors, any of his or their fortrefles, fortilefles or holds, within this realm, or any other the King’s dominions or marches,-or rebellioufly detain, keep, or withhold from the King’s (aid Highnefs, his heyres or fucceflors, any of his or their (hips, ordnances, artillery, or other munitions or fortifications of war, and doe not humbly render and give up to our faid foveraign Lord, his heyres or fucceflors, or to fuch perfons as fhall be deputed by them, fuch caftles, fortrefles, fortilefles, holds, (hips, ordnances* artillery, and other munitions and fortifications of war rebellioufly kept, or detayned, within fixe dayes next after they fhaU be commanded, by our faid foveraign Lord, his heyres and fucceflors, by open proclamations under the great feale : that then every fuch perfon and perfons fo offending in any of the premifl'es, after the laid, firft day of February, their aydors, oounfaylors, con-fentors, and abbettors, being thereof lawfully convicted, according to the laws and cuftomes of this realme, fhall be adjudged traditours ; and that every fuch offence in any the premifles that fhall be committed of done after the firft day of February, fhall be reputed, accepted, and adjudged high treafon, and the oft'endors therein, and their aydors,

II.	And to the inteut that all treafons Ihould be the more dread, hated, and detefted to be done by any perfon or perfons, and alfo becaufe it is a great boldnefs, and an oc-cafion to evil difpofed perfons to adventure and embrace their malicious intents and enterprifes, which all true fub-je&s ought to ftudie to efchue: be it therefore ena&ed by authority aforefaid, that none offendor, in any kinds ofhign treafons whatfoever they be, their ay dors, cbnfentors, coun-failors and abbettors, shall be admitted to have the benefit or privileges of any manner of sanctuary, confidering, that matters of treafons toucheth fo nigh, both the fuertie of the King our (bveraign lord his perfon, his heyres and fucceftors.

III. CHAP. XIII.

An A3 again]} the Authority of the Bijbop of Rome. Rot. Pari. cap. 23.

FORASMUCH, as notwithftanding the good and hoi-fom lawes, ordinances, and ftatutes heretofore made* enabled and eftabliftied by the King’s highnefs our moil gracious foveraign lord, and by the whole confent of this nigh court of Parliament, for the extirpation, abolition, and extinguiftiment out of this land, of the pretended Mifchitf at- power, ana ufurpdd authority of the bifhop of Rome (by tending the fome called the Pope) ufed within the fame, which did ob-Pope s autho- fufcat and God’s holy word and teftament a long fea-fon from the fpiritual and true meaning thereof, to his worldly and carnal affeftion, as pompe, glorie, avarice, am-bicion, and tyranny, covering and fhadowing the fame with his humane and craftie devxfes, traditions, and inventions fet forth under the cloke of vertue, only to promote and eftablifh his dominion afwel both upon the foulcs and bodies, as alfo upon the temporal goods of all chriftan people, excluding not only Chrift out of his kingdom and rule of man’s foule as much as they might, but alfo other temporal Kings and Princes out of their dominions, which they ought to have by God’s law, upon the bodies and goods of their fubje&s, whereby he did not only robbe the King’s Majeftie, being onely the lupreme head of the realm of England, and of this his land of Ireland immediately under God, of his honor, right, and prehemincnce due unto, him by the law of God, but alfo fpoyled this his land of Ireland yearly of innumerable treafure, and befides the Ioffes of the fame, deceived the King’s loving and obedient fubje&s, perfwading to them by his lawes, bulls, and other his deceivable meanes, fuch dreames, vanities and fantafies, as by the fame many of them were feduced and conveyed unto fuperftidous and erronious opinions, fo that the King’s Majeftie, the lord’s fpiritual and temporal, and the commons in this his land being overwearied and fatigued with

7%e t wenty-eighth Year 0/Henry the Eighth. defendour of the faith, lord of Ireland, and fupreame head in earth of the church of England, and from thence adjourned to Weftminiler, and Toy divers prorogations there holden and continued, it was and is ena&ed amongft other things, in maner and forme as followeth: Moft humbly be-feechen your moft royal Majeftie, your obedient and faithful fubjetts, the commons in this prefent Parliament affem-bled by your moft dread commanaement, that where your fubje&s of this your realme, and of other countries and dominions being under your obeyfance by many yeares paft, have beene and yet be greatly decayed and impove-riftied by fueh intollerable exactions of great fummes of mony as hath been claymed and taken, and yet continually be claymed to be taken out of this your realme, and other your faid countreys and dominions, by the bilhop of Rome* called the Pope, and the fee of Rome, as well m penfions, cences, Peter-pence, procurations, fruits, fuits for provi-ftons, and expeditions of bulls for archbilhoprickes and bi-fhoprickes, and for delegacies and referips in caufes of contentions and appeales, jurifdiftions legative, and alfo for dil'penlations, licenfes, faculties, graurfts, relaxations, writs called (perinde valere) rehabilitations, abolicions, and other infinite forts of bulls, breeves and inftruments of fundry natures, names, and kindes, in great numbers, heretofore pra&ifed and obtayned, otherwife then by the Jawcs, laudable ufes and cuftomes of this realme ihould be permitted, the fpecialties whereof been over long, large in number, and tedious here particularly to be inferted, wherein the bifhop of Rome aforefaid hath not beene only to be blamed for his ufurpation in the premises, but a!u> for his abufion and beguiling your fubje&s; pretending and perfwading to them that he hath full power to difpence with all human lawes, ufes, and cuftomes of all realmes in all caufes, which be called fpiritual; which matter hath beene ufurped and pra£tifed by him and his predeceflors by many yeares in great derogation of your imperial crown, and authority royal, contrarie to the right and confcience; for where this your grace’s realme, recognifing no fuperiour under God but onely your Grace, hath beene and yet is free from fubje£tion to any man’s lawes, but onely to fuch as have been devifed, made, and ordained within this realms for the wealth of the fame, cr to fuch other as by (utterance of your Grace and your progenitors the people of this realme have taken at their free liberty, by their own confent, to be ufed among them, and have bound themfelves by long life and cuftome to the obfervance of the famine*, as to the obfervance of the lawes of any forreigne prince, potentate, or prelate, but as to the accuftomed and auncient lawes of this realme, originally eftablilhed as lawes of the (ame by the faid fufferance, confent, and caftomes, and

none

$*bt twenty-eighth Ttdr ef Henry the Eighth. tone otherwife It ftandeth therefore with natural equitie and good reafon, that in all and every fuch lawes human, made within this realme, or induced into this realrae by the Aid fufterance, confentes, and cuftome, your royall Majeftie, and your lords fpiritual and temporal, and commons reprefenting the whole ftate of your realme, und this

VI.	And forafmuch as the charges of the obtayning if the faid licences, difpenfarions, faculties, and other rescripts, or writings aforenamed, at the court of Rome by the lofles, exchanges, and in conducing of currours, and waging foli-citours to (he for any fuch licences, difpenfations, faculties, inftruments, and otner referipts or writings, have beene grievous and exccffive to your people; and many rimes greater fummes have beene demaunded for the fpeedie expedition in the court of Rome, than be exprefled in the old taxe Unfitted to be payed for the faid expeditions, whereby your people have been brought to an uncertainty upon the payment for expeditions of fuch things, and by reaibn thereof have been conftrained to pay more, then they were wont to doe, to the great impoveriftiing of this realme as, is aforefaid : and fometimes the fpeeding of fuch difpenfa-, tions, faculties, licences, and other writings at Rome have been fo long deferred, that the parties labouring for dae fame have fuffered great incommodities and Ioffes for lacke of quick fpcede, which hereafter may be had within this

difpenfations,

C H A P. xxir.

An A3 for the We ares upon the B arrow, and other Waters in the County of Kilkenny. Rot. Pari. cap. ?6.

PRAYEN the commons of this prefent Parliament af-fembled, that where at all times neccffarie boates, fcowts, wherries, clarans, ccttcs, and other veffek, loden and bellowed with goods, merchandizes, and other Huff?, have beene ufed to pafle and repalfe thorough and in the King’s moll excellent Majelly’s rivers and waters of the Barrow, the Noyre, the Suyr, ard the Rie, within this land, which Rie is in the county of Kilkenny, to and from the King’s citie of Waterford, and the townes of Kilkenny, Roffe, and Clomel, to and from diverfe borrowe and corporate townes, and other places, being fuuated in the counties of Kyldare, Catherlagh, Wexford, Kilkenny, Waterford, and Tipperary', throu gh which great com mod; tie and profit hath growen and might grow to the faid citie, townes, boruughes, and other places, and to all and every the King’s true fubje&s adjoyning to the fame waters and rivers: and yet this notwith (landing new of late rivers wilful perfons, having no refpett to the premises, but more rather to their own wilfulnefle, lingular com modi tie,' and benefite, having no ground ne caufc reafonable to the famCj have in divers places of the faid rivers and waters made fuch weres, purpreffures, ingincs, {Ircites, and other like obftacles, and them and every of them fo do keep and ttiaintaine, that by no meanes any boates, fcowts, wherries, clarans, cottes, and other veffels, laden and bellowed as is aforefaid, can conveniently palfe and repalfe ; and through which the falmon frie, breeding in the faid waters and rivers, be cleerly dellroyed, contrarie to the effect and purport of the llatutes therein provided ; and in divers fundry places of the faid rivers and waters alfo doe take, and procure to be taken, divers exa&ions and unlawful cudomes, called bankfees, of any boate, fcowt, wherrie, clarane, coil, and other veffell, laden and bellowed, as is aforefaid, going and palling in and through the King’s faid rivers and waters; albeit that part of the faid borough townes by their liberties and charters be freely and quite difeharged of all manner tolles, paffages, xuftomes, and pondages in the faid rivers and waters, and the land on every fide of the fame : and that alfo fuch* perfon and perfons, as be the boatemen, and have the rule, governance, and conveying of faid boates, fcoutes, wherries, clarans, cottes, and other veffels, laden and bellowed as is aforefaid, at fuch times as they be laden with wines, of their deceipt and craftie means doc from time to time draw, drink, and take ......	with

mm

An Ail for gray Merchants»

Chap. 6.

Two evils provided for.

Divorces on pfctence of former con-trad.

Pifpenfation invented by Rome.

The thirty-third Tear of Henry the Eighth. ter might kindle a great fire, and To remayning, his powep not to feeme utterly extin& : therefore it is thought moft convenient to the King’s highnefle, and to his lords fpiri-tuall and temporall, with the commons of this land a/Tem-bled in this prefent Parliament, That two things fpecially for this time be with diligence provided for, whereby many inconveniences hath eniued, and many moe evils mought enfue and follow: as where heretofore diverfe and many perfons after long continuance together in martrimonie, without any allegation of eyther of the parties, or anie other at their marriage, why the fame matrimonie ftionld, not bee good, juft, and lawfull, and after the fame matrimonie folemnized and confummate by camall copulation, and alfo fometimes fruite of<hildren enfued of the fame marriage, have neverthelefle by an unjuft law of the bifhop of Rome, which is, that upon pretence of a former contract made and not confummate by carnall knowledge, for proofe wheteof two witnefles by that law were onely required, beene di-vorfed and feparated contrarie to God’s law ; and fo the true matrimonie both folempnifed in the f%ce of the church, and confummate with bodily knowledge, and confirmed alfo with the fruit of children had betwixt them, cleerely fruftrate and diflblved : further alfo, by reafon of other prohibitions then God’s law admitteth, for their lucre by that court invented, the difpenfation whereof they alwayes referred to themfelfe, as in kindred or affinitic betwixt cofen germanes, and fo to fourth and fourth degree, carnal knowledge of any of the fame kinne or affinity, before in fuch outward degrees, which all were lawful, and be not prohibited by God’s law, and all becaufe they would get money by it and keepe a reputation to their ufurped jurifdi&ion, whereby not onely much difeord be betwixt lawfull married perfons hath (contrary to God’s ordinance) arifen, much debate and fuit at the law, with the wrongfull vexation and great dammage of the innocent partie hath beene procured, and many juft marriages in doubt and danger < of undoing, and alfo many times undone, and lawful hevres difenherited, whereof they had never elfe, but for his veine glorious ufurpation, beene moved any fuch quef-tion fithence freedome was in them was given us by God’a law, which ought to be moft fure and certaine : but that notwithftar.ding, marriages have beene brought into fuch an uncertaintie thereby, that no marriage could be fo fure knitte and bounden, but it fhould lye in eyther of the parties powers and arbitre, carting away the fcare of God, by meanesand compafll* to prove a precontract, a kindred and $llyance, or carnal knowledge, to defeat the fime: and fo under the pretence of thefe allegations afore rehearfed to live all the daves of t!>cir life in detclhble adulteric, to the ttftcr dcftru&ion of their owne foules, and the provocation

The third and fourth Years of PHILIP and MARY. CHAP. VI.

CHAP. H.

An 43 for the Uniformitie of Common Prayer and Service in the Church, and the Adminiftration of the Sacraments.

Ill

A. D.

1560.

TT7HERE at the death of oar late foverain lord King x aEmg. VV Edward the 6. there remained one uniforme order

of common fervice, prayer, and of the adminiftration of facraments, rites and ceremonies in the church of England, which was fet forth in one book, intituled, *• the Book of “ Common Prayer, and adminiftration of Sacraments, and “ other rites and ceremonies in the church of England,” authorifed by aft of Parliament, holden in the faid realm of England, in the fifth and fixth years of our faid late foveraign lord King Edward the 6. intituled. An ad for the St. $ &6 uniformitie of common prayer, and adminiftration of the fa- £. 6, r. Eng. craments; the which was repealed and taken away by aft of Book of com-Parliament in the faid realm of England, in the firft year mon Pr*yc£ of the raign of our late foveraign lady Queen Mary, to the ffc* great decay of the due honour of God, and difeomfort to ^forcc. me profeffors of the truth of Chrift’s religion. Be it therefore enafted by the authoritie of this prefent Parliament,

That the faid book with the order of iervice, and of the adminiftration of facraments, rites and ceremonies, with the alteration and additions therein added and appointed by this eftatute, shall ftand and bee from and after the feaft of Penticoft, next enfuing, in full force and effeft, according to the tenour and effeft of this eftatute.

An A Si for the Conferring and Confeerating of Archbijhops and Bijbops within this Readme. Rot. Pari. cap. 4.

An A& far the Prefrrvation of Salmon Erie and Ele Frit.

Hot. Pari. cap. 13.

FORASMUCH as great hurt and hindrance doeth daily grow to the Queen’s Majeftie’s fubjedto within thia realm by reafon that the inhabitants of diverfe cities and townes within this fame adjoyning neere to rivers, that doth ebbe and flow, wherein the frye of falmon, ele, and other commodious fifties are bred and nourifhed, doth keep herds and number of fwine, and alfo doth ufe at the ebbe or low water to fuffer their faid fwine to feed upon the ftrands of the faid rivers, where they deftroy great quantitie of falmon and ele frye, and frye of fpaune of divers other good fifties, to (he great hurt and hindrance of fiftiing, and to the great hindrance and damage of the common-wealth : be it therefore ena&ed by the authoritie of this prefent Parliament,

The eleventh Tear of Elizabeth. Seff. 3. CHAP. X.

An AS for tbi Staying of Wool, Flocks, fallow, and other Necejfaries within this Realm. Rot, Pari. cap. 20.

FOR that that diverfe die commodities of this realm are carried and tranfported out of the fame by fandrie private covetoufe perfons to the great hurt and damage thereof; and aUb for that fuch perfons ufe, as well by dealing, as by open conveying of the fame, as well by fi-cenfe as without licenfe, to anfwer fmall or no cuftom at all for them, whereby the Queen’s Majefties cuftomea and revenues are greatly leffened and diminifhed within this realm : and to the intent alfo. That the Queen’s Majefties coftoraes and revenues might be increafed and augmented, and that the faid commodities might bee more abundantly wrought within this realm* ere they shall be tranfported, then prefently they are, which shall fet many now living id lie on work, to the great reliefe and commoditie of this realm: and alfo to the end that Englilh artificers of the realm of England may be by the aboundance of the faid commodities within this realm allured to come into the fame to work them within this realm, and thereby to give enfam-ple to others to ufe that trade to the great commoditie and profit of this realm : For remedie whereof, at the humble petition of the whole commons of this realm, be it eaa&ed by our foveraign lady, the Queen’s Hiebnefle, by the aftent of the lords fpirituall and temporal!, and the commons in this Parliament aflembled, and by authoritie of the fame, that whatfoever perfon or perfons shall from or after the laft day of September, which shall be in the year of our lord God, 1569, put, carrie, or load into any fhip, bark, pickard, boat, or other veflfell, any wool, flockes, fiaxe, linen yarne, woollen yame, (heepefell, calfefell, goatfell, redd deerfell, or fallow deerfell unwrought, beefe, tallow, waxe, or butter, to the intent to carrie the fame out of this realm, shall pay for the fame to the Queen’s Majeftie, her heyres and (uccefiours, for cuftome for the fame as hereafter enfueth, videlicet, for every fuch (lone of wooll and flockes five (hillings fterling; and for every fuch pound of flaxe, linnen yame, and woollen yame, twelve pence fter-ling; and for everie fuch (hecpfell, calfefell, and goatfell, foure pence fterling : and for every redd deerfell two (hillings Gx pence fterling : and for every fallow deerfell twende pence fterling; II.	And be it further enacted by authoritie aforefaid, that if the owner, purfer, or any other officer or matter of any (hipp, barque, pyckard, boat, or other veflell, in which any woole, flockes, flaxe, lynnen yam, woollen yam, (heep-fell, calfefell, goatfell, redde deerfell, or fallow deerfell, tin wrought, beefe, tallow, waxe, or butter shall be em-barqued or put, doe permit or fuffer from the laft day of September next coming, any perfon or perfons to imbarque or put aboard or bring into any his the owners (hipp, barque, pyckard, boat, or other veflell, or other his the owners veflell, any parceil or parcetlsof the premifles before the Queen’s Majeftie, her heyres or fuccettours, is cuf-tome for tbe fame be truely anfwered and payed in this realm, and before payment and fatisfadion of the cuttome and cuftomes aforefaid due unto the faid cide or corporate towne and corporation aforefaid, as in this ad before is al-ledged, that then eveiy fuch (hipp, barque, pyckard, boat, or other veflel shall be torfeyted ; the one halfe of the fame to our foveraigne Lady the Queen’s Majeftie, her heyres and fuccettours, and the other halfe to fuch perfon or perfons as (ball prefent or informe the fame before the barons of the Exchequer for the time being in the faid realm, and that withrn twelve wcekes after the faid forfey-ture.

III.	And it is further enacted by authorise aforefaid, that the fercher, his depude, fador, or attorney of any port, haven, or creek within this realm, where any fuen wooll, flockes, flaxe, lynnen yam, woollen yam, (heepfell, calfefell, or goatfell, red deerfell, and fallow deerfell unwrought, beef, tallow, waxe, or butter, shall after the faid (irft day of September next comming bee put, carried, or loaden in any (hip, barke, pyckard, boate, or other veflell, knowing the fame to be 10 put, carried, or loaden, will conceale the fame by the fpace of twelve weeks, next after the fame bee put or loaden in any (hipp, barque, py-kard, boate, or other veflell, without information thereof to the barons of the Exchequer of this realm for the time being, that the fame concealment in the fearcher, his de-putie, fador, or atturney, and every of them that fo will conceal the fame, putting, carrying, or loading of any the premifles, shall be adjudged ana deemed felony; for which they shall fuffer pains of death, and forfeiture of goods onely.

IV.	Provided that this ad extend not to any lord or lordes, prelate, or any of the Queen’s Majefties privle council, to take flocke bedes under the weight of three

The twelfth Year of ELIZABETH.

CHAP. I.

An A3 for the Ere 3 ion of Free Schoolet.

cap. 5.

Rot. ParL

7 Will. J 4. 11 G. 19. 29 G. 2. 7.

FORASMUCH as the greated number of the people of this your Majedie’s realm hath of long time lived in rude and barbarous dates, not underdanding that Almigh-tie God hath by his divine laws forbidden the manifold and haynous offences, which they fpare not daily and hourely to commit and perpetrate, nor that hee hath by his holy Scriptures commanded a due and humble obedience from the people to their princes and rulers; whole ignorance in thele fo high pointes touching their damnation proceedeth only of lack of good bringing up of the youth of this realm either in publique or private ichooles, where through good difcipline they might be taught to avoide thefe lotn-lome and horrible errours : it may therefore pleafe your mod excellent Majeftie, that it be enafted, and be it enaft-ed by your Highneffe with the affent of the lords fpirituall and temporall and the commons in this prefent Parliament affembled, and by the authoritie of the fame. The twepty-eighth Year of ELIZABETH.

CHAP. I.

An A& concerning lYillfull Perjurie.

FORASMUCH as this realm of Ireland is greatly troubled and hindered by reaibn of wiifull perjurie daily committed notwithftanding that many good lawes have been made and ordeyned for ml refs thereof, and for that great dangers and perilles are daily like to fall, if fome further remedies shall not be fpeedily provided for prevention thereof ; be it therefore enafted by otfr Sovereign Lady the Queen,

CHAP. VI.

An A SI againjf Forging and Counterfeyting of forrein Coyne* &c. Rot. Pari. cap. 8.

FORASMUCH as by the lawes or ftatutes of this realm, fmall or no condigne puniftiment is at this time

Eng Vide & 24 G. 3. c. 50. _

provided for fuch evil difpofed perfons, as shall counterfit Counterfeit- or forge fuch kind of gold or filver of other realms, as i* ir.^ foreign not the proper coyne of this realm, nor currant in payment ©f hi ^tieafon0 ^t^in reRlm» by reafon whereof, divers evill difpofed •	perfons, as well without this realm, as within, are encou-

raged and boldened daily to counterfeyte or forge fuck kind of gold and filver, and utter the fame in this realm, in great decay of her Majefties fubjefts : be it enafted by our foveraigne lady the Queen’s Majeftie, the lords fpiri-

CHAP. IV.

An A3 that this Sejfion of Parliament Jhall not Determine by his Majefties Royal AJJent to Jome Bills. Rot. Pari, cap. 3.

CHAP, II.

An Aft how Lands, Tenements, Src. map he Ufooftd by Witt or otherwi/e, and concerning Wards and Primer Seizin.

\T/HERE the King’s moil Royal Majefty, in all the naming this a&. VV time of his mod gracious and noble raigne, hath ever beene a mercifull, loving, benevolent, and mod gracious Sovereign Lord, unto all and fmgular his loving and , obedient fubjefts, in fuch wife as all his faid fubjefts be mod bounden to the uttermeft of all their powers and graces, by them received of God, to render and give unto his Majedy their mod humble reverence and obedient thanks and fervices, with their dayly and continuall prayer to Almighty God, for the continuall prefervation of his mod royall eftate in mod kingly honour and profperity; yet alwayes his Majedy being repleat, and endowed by God with Grace, goodnefte and UberaHty, mod tenderly confi* dering, that his faid obedient and loving fubjefts cannot ufe and exercife themfelves according to their edates, degrees, faculties and qualities, or to beare themfelves in fuch wi(e, as that they may conveniently keep and mantaine their hof-pitality and families, nor the good education and bringing up of their lawfull generations, which in this realme (laud be to God) is in all parts very great and aboundant, but that in manner of neceffity, as by dayly experience is mani-feftid and knowne; they shall not be able of their proper gords, chattels, and other moveable fub(lance, to difeharge their debts, and after their degrees, fet forth and advance their children and pofterity : wherefore, our faid Sovereign Lord, mod vertuoufly con&dering the mortality that is in every perfon at God's will and pleafore mod common and

uncertaine.

An A3 againfl covenous and fraudulent Conveyances.

CHAP. Y.

An A3 for the Recovery of Arrearages of Rents by Executors of Tenant in Fee Simple.

FORASMUCH as by the order of the common law, 51H. 8. $7.

the executors or adminiftrators of tenants in fee fimple, Eng. tenants in fee tayle, and tenants for tearm of lives, of rents fcrvices, rents charges, rents feckes, and fee farms, have No remedy no remedy to recover fuch arrerages of the faid rents or for arrears of fee farmes, as were due unto their teftators in their lives, rents by com-nor yet the heires of fuch teftators, nor any perfons having 100,1 “w* the reverfion of his eftate after his deceafe, may diftraine or have any lawfull adion to levy any fuch arrerages of rents, or of the fee farms due unto him in his life, as is aibrefaid* by reafon whereof the tenants of the demeafne of fuch lands, tenements, or hereditaments, out of the which fuch rents were due and payable, who of right ought to pay the rents and farms at fuch dayes and tearmes as they were due, doe many times keep, hold and rctaine fuch arrerages in ther owne hands, fo that the executors and adminiftrators of the perfons to whom fuch rents or fee farms were due, cannot have or come by the faid arrerages of the fame, towards the payment of the debts, and performance of the will of the faid teftator; for remedy whereof, be it enaded by the authority of this prefent Parliament, that the executors and Executors, fcc. adminiftrators of every fuch perfon or perfons unto whom have debt any fuch rent or fee farme is or shall be due, and not paid	t^a-

at the time of his death, shall and may have an adion of tor# 9 debt for all fuch arrerages againft the tenant or tenants that ought to have paid the faid rent or fee f^rme, fo being behind in the life of their teftator, or againft the executors and adminiftrators of the faid tenants. And alfo furthermore it shall be lawful to every fuch executor and adminif-trator of any fuch perfon or perfons, unto whom fuch rent or fee farme shall be due, ana not paid at the time of his death, as is aforefaid, to diftraine for the arrerages of all fuch rents and fee farme upon the lands, tenements, and other hereditaments, which were charged with the payment of 'fuch rents or fee farmes, and chargeable to tne diftrefle of the faid teftator fo long as the faia lands, tenements or hereditaments, continue, remaine, and be in the feifin or poffeffion of the faid tenant in demeafne, who ought immediately, to have paid the faid rent or fee farme fo being behind to the faid teftator in his life, or in the feifon or pofteffion of any other perfon or perfons claiming the faid lands, tenements and hereditaments, onely by and from the

CHAP. VII.

An A SI that <wrongfull DiJ/eizin, Sc c. is no Dcfccnt in Law.

H. 8 33. "TXTHERE divers perfons of their infatiable minds have ' m	VV	heretofore	by	ftrength	and without title, entred into

DifTcifor mannors, lands, tenements, and other hereditaments, and yinS c 1 • wrongfully diffeized the right owners and pofleflors thereof;

and over, being feized by aifieizin, have thereof died feized, by reafon of which dying feized, the difleizee, or fuch other perfons as before fuch defeent might have lawfully entred into the faid mannors, lands, and tenements, were and be thereby clearly excluded of their entry into the faid mannors, lands, and tenements, and put to their aftion for their remedy and recovery therein, to their great coft and charges; for reformation whereof, be it enafted by the authority of this prefent Parliament, That the dying feized hereafter of any fuch diffeizor, of, or in any mannors, lands, tenements, or other hereditaments, having no right or title therein, shall not be taken or deemed from henceforth any fuch defeent in the law, for to tolle or take away the entry of any fuch perfon or perfons, or their heircs, which at the time of the fame defeent, had good and lawfull title of entry into the faid mannors, lands, tenements, or hereditaments, except that fuch diffeizor hath had the peaceable 'poffeffion of fuch mannors, lands, tenements, or hereditaments, whereof he shall fo dye feized by the fpace of five years next after the difTeizin by him committed, without entry or continual clayme, by or of fuch perfon or perfons as have lawfull title thereunto.

CHAP. VIII.

CHAP. X.

An A SI for tbe Reformation of Errors in Fines and Recoveries.

FOR the appeafing of fuites, the avoiding of falfe practices, deccipts, devices, and mifdemeanors, and for the helping of negligences and mi£prifions of clearkes and officers, dangerous to affurances of men’s lands and hereditaments ; bee it ena&ed by our Soveraign Lord the King’s Majefty, the lords fpirituall and temporally and the commons in this prefent Parliament affrmbled, and by the authority of the fame. That every writ of covenant and other writ, whereupon any fine heretofore hath been levyed, or hereafter shall be levyed, the returne thereof, the writ of dedimus pot eft at em, made for the knowledging of any of the fanifc fines, the return thereof, the concord, note, and foote of every fuch fine, the proclamations made thereupon, and the King’s filver, and alfo every originall writ of entry in the poll, or other writ, whereupon any common recovery hath been fuffered, or hereafter shall be fuffered or paffed, the writs of fummons ad warrantiooandumy the returnes of the faid originals and writs of fummons ad warrantizandum, and every warrant of attourney had or to be had, as well of every demandant and tenant, as vouchee extant and remaining, or that shall be extant and in being, may upon the requeft or eledlion of any perfon bcb inrolled in rolls of parchment by the clarke or proper officer, in or by the fame court appointed or to be appointed for that purpofe, and for fuch reafonable fees as that court from time to time shall appoint; and that the inroliments of the fame, or of any part thereof, shall be of as good force and validity in law, to all intents, refpetts and purpofes, for fo much of any of them fo inrolled, as the fame being extant and remaining, were or ought by law to be.

IT. And be it further enabled by the authority aforefaid. That no fine, proclamations upon fines, or common recovery heretofore had, levied, fuffered or paffed, or hereafter to be had, levyed, fuffered or paffed, shall be reverfed, or reverfable by any writ of error for falfe or incongruous la-tine, rafore, interlyning, mif-entrir.g of any warrant of attourney, or of any proclamation, milreturning, or not returning of the (hertffe or other want of forme in words, and not in matter of (ubftance.

CHAP. XIV.

jfn Aft for the Continuance of Aftions afer the Death of any King.

WHEREAS the King’s fubjefts heretofore have, ta their great charges, cofts and expences, profccuted and fued divers and fundry aftions, as well reall and per-fotiall, as all other aftions mixt, or otherwife, in the King’s Majefties courts, and other courts of records, not onelv by writs, but alfo by plaints or bills; which aftions, luits, bills and plaints, by the death or demife of the King’s of this realm, have been difeontinued, and the parties in every fuch aftions, fuits, bills and plaints, thereby have been put without day, whereby the demaundants, plaintiffes and aftors, in every fuch aftion and fuite, were compelled and driven, by the order of the laws of this realm, for their further remedy, further to commence or begin againe his or their faid aftions, fuits, or plaints, or elfe to profecute and fue, re-fummons, re-attachments, feire facias, or fuch other like procefle, to revive his or their faid aftions, fuits, or plaints, which was not onely to their great cofts, charges, expences, hindrances and delay of their caufes and fuits, but alfo a great lett and hindrance of juftice. For reforma- Suits flail tion whereof, be it ordained, eftablilhed, and enafted by not \>e difeonti-the King our foveraigne lord, and the lords and commons nued upon in this prefent Parliament aflembled, and by the authority of the fame. That from henceforth, by the death or demile of the King’s Majefty that now is, (whofe life. Almighty God long preferve, keep, and maintaine in his moft royall eftate) nor by the death or demife of any that hereafter lhall be King of this realm, any aftion, fuit, bill, or plaint, now or that hereafter lhall depend between party and party, in any of the courts aforefaid, lhall not in any wife be difeontinued, or put without day ; but that the procefle, pleas, demurrers, and continuances in every aftion, aftions, fuits, bills or plaints, which now, or that hereafter lhall depend, lhall ftand good and effeftuall, and be profccuted and fued forth, in fuch manner and form, and in the fame eftate, condition and order, as if the fame King had lived and continued in full life ; the death or de-mife hereafter of any King of this realm, notwithftanding.

And that all and all manner of judiciall procefle, that hereafter lhall be had or purfued, in the time of the raigne of any other King than raigned at the time of the purfuit of the originall, or other former procefle, lhall be made in the , i name of the King that for the time lhall raigne, and be King of this realm, and that variance touching the fame •

The tenth Tear of Charles I. SefT. 2. CHAP. XVIII.

Aft appointing an Order to Juftices of Peace, touching the Bailment, committing and taking Examination of Pri-fonersy &c.

WHERE in the Parliament holden at Weftminfter, in the third yeare of the raigne of the noble Prince King Henry the feventh, it was among other things ordained and enafted, “ that no prifoner, arrefted for felony, Ihould be letten to baile or mainprife, by any one juftice of peace, but by the whole juftices, or at lead by two of them, whereof one to be of the quorum lince the making of which ftatute, one juftice of peace, in the name of himielfe, and one other of the juftices, his companion, not making the faid juftice party nor privy unto the cafe wherefore the prifoner Ihould be bailed, hath oftentimes, by finifter labour and means, fet at large the greateft offendors, fuch as be not replevifable by the laws of this realme, and yet the rather to hide their affeftions in that behalfe have Signified the caufe of their apprehenfion to be but onely for fufpicion of felony, whereby the (aid offendors have efcaped un-punifhed, and doe daily to the high difpleafure of Almighty God, the great perill of the King’s true fubje&s, and encouragement of all theeves and e\ill doers : For reformation whereof, be it ordained and enabled by the King’s moil excellent Majefty, the lords fpirituall and temporall, and the commons in this prefent Parliament affembled, and by authority of the fame. That from and after the firft day of May next enfuing, no juftice or juftices of peace, shall let to baile or mainpraife, any fuch perfon or perfons, which for any offence or offences, by them or any of tl\em committed, be declared not to be replevied or bailed, or be forbidden to be replevied or bailed by the ftatute of Weft- None fhall be minfter the firft, made in the Parliament holden in the third lct t0 ^ yeare of the reign of King Edward the firft : And further- bijdcn^bc1^-more, that any perfon or perfons, arrefted for man-flaugfiter plevicdoi bailed or felony, or fufpicion of man-flaughter or felony, being by ft Weftmin-baileabl’e by the law, fhall not after the faid firft day oflfcr 1. 3 £. 1. The tenth Year of Charles I. Seff. 2. CHAP. XIX.

An A3 for the Triall of Murders and Felonies committed in /overall Counties, &C.

ORASMUCH as the mod neceffary office and duty of

law is to preferv* and fave the life of man, and con-dignely to punifh fuch perfons that unlawfully or willfuDy murther, flay or deftroy men ; and alfo that another ofHce and duty of law is to punilh robbers and thieves, w hich daily endeavour themfelves to rob and fteale, or give aflitl-ance to the fame, and yet by craft and cautile, doe efcape from the fame without punilhment; and where it often happened and cometh in ure in fundry counties of this real me, that a man is felonioufly ftrucken in

cafes of that nature, it hath not been found by the law's and cuftomes of this real me, that any fufficient indittment thereof can be taken in any of the faid two counties, for that by the cuftomes of this realme, the jurors of the county where fuch party dyed of fuch ftroke, can take no knowledge of the laid ftroke, being in a forreigne county, although the fame two counties and places adjoine very neer together, nor the jurors of the county where the ftroke was given, cannot take knowledge of the death in any other county, although fuch death moft apparently came of the fame ftroke; fo that the King’s Majefty within his owne realme cannot by any lawes, yet made or knowne, punilh fuch murderers or man-killers, for offences in this form committed and done, nor any appeale at fome time may lye for the fame, but doth alfo faile, and the laid murderers and man-killers efcape thereof without punilhment, as well in cafes where the counties where fuch offences be committed and done, may joyne, or otherwife where they may not joyne. And alfo it is a common praftife among arrant thieves and robbers in this realme, that after they have robbed or ftollen in one county, they will convey their fpoilc, or part thereof, fo robbed and ftoilen, unto fome of their adherents, in fome other county where the principall offence was not committed or done, wh# knowing of fuch felony, willingly, and by falfe covin, receive the fame ; in which cafe, although the principal felon be attainted in the one county, the acceffary efcapeth by rca-fon that her was acceffary in another county, and that the jurors of the faid other county, by any la\y yet made, can take no knowledge of the principall felony nor attainder in the firft county, and fo fuch acceffaries efcape thereof un-punilhed, and do often put in ure the fame, knowing that they may elcape without punilhment; For redreffe and pu-luihment of which offences, and other offences of like na-

CHAP. xxr.

An As for the reflrayning of all Per fans from Marriage, untill their former Wives andformer Hujband be dead.

Bigamy made and others. Be it therefore enafted by the King’s Ma jefty, felony.	with confent of the lords fpirituall and temporall, and

CHAP. XXIII.

An A3 to avoyde and prevent diver fe Mifdemeanors in idle and lewd Per Jons in barking of Trees, &c.

TO

FORASMUCH as unlawfull cutting and taking away of com and graine growing, robbing of orchards and gardens, digging up, or taking away of fruite trees, breaking of hedges, pales, or other fences, cutting or fpoyling of woods or underwoods (landing and growing, barking of growing trees, and fiich like offences, are now more committed by lewd and meane perfons, than in former times, and that the laid offences are great caufes of the maintaining of idleneffe, and the perfons which commit the fame are not for the mofl part able, nor have wherewith to make recompence or fatisfa&ion ; be it therefore enadted by the au- Cutting or thority of this prefent Parliament, That all and every fuch taking com lewd perfon and perfons, which from and after the firft day ^^orSards or of May now next following lhall cut, or unlawfully take gar3cnN breakaway any corn or grayn growing, or rob any orchards or in» fences, pul- -gardens, or breake or cut any hedge, pales, railes or fence hng uo fruit or digge, pull up, or take up any fruit tree or trees in any trce8» "arj“nS orchard, garden, or elfewhere, to the intent to take and ^(not'be-carry the fame away, or lhall barke any tree or trees that ing felony.) are growing, or lhall cut or fpoile any woods or underwoods, poles or trees Handing, not being felony'by the laws of this realme, and their procurer, or procurers, re- And procur-ceiyer or receivers knowing the fame, being thereof lawfully ers or receiver*, convidled by the confeflion of the party, or by the tefti-mony of one fufficient witneffe upon oath before fome one juftice of the peace, major, bayliffe, or other head officer, which lhall have power by force of this ftatute to minifler the faid oath (where the offence fhall be committed, or the party offending apprehended) fhall give the party and par- To fPve reties fuch recompence and fatisfa&ion for his and their dam-	^

fundry plantations have at feverall times been made in the feverall counties of Waterford, Corkc, Limiricke, Kerry,

Tipperary, Wexford, Wickeloe, King’s County, Queen’s County, Weftmeath, Leitrim, Longford, Tyrone, Armagh,

Donegal!, Farmanagh, Cavan and Londonderry, grounded as well upon ancient as recent title of your crown, declared as well by inquifitions as other records and evidences ; upon all which divers patents have been patted, and thereby unikrwk * very many under-takers, and others of Brittifh birth, and ™tdcd. cr very many of the natives of beft quality and condition have been there planted and fettled, and feverall lands, tenements and hereditaments granted and difpofed to corporations, forts, incumbents of churches, fchooles and other good ufes ; fome other parcells of the faid lands being one-ly diftributed and afligned, and not pafTed by reafon of re-ftraints for fome years part; by occafion of all which, very many cables, bawnes, ftrong houfes, forts and townes walled, have lincebeen built and erected, and innumerable in-clofures and improvements made, and alfo feverall tradef-men of Brittifh birth, and manufactures have been thither brought and conduced by the under-takers, fervitors, natives and others, to their very great charge and expence, willingly performed to the terror and difcourageinent of all evill difpofed perfons, to the unexpected enriching and civilizing of the faid feverall counties and territories, and to the great joy and contentment of your royall Majefty, and all good men, inlomuch as by the great blefling of Almighty God upon your Majeftie’s molt gracious and fiic-ceflefull government, thofe places and countries which heretofore have been onely dilturbance to all your Ma-jefties loving fubjeCts of Ireland, and burthen, lottfe, dilho-nour, and expence of the crown of England, have now been enabled to yeeld and afford to your molt excellent Majefty, as ample and beneficiall an ayde and fupply to all levies, and to the now granted fubfidies, as any other proportionable parfs of this kingdom have done, and for the future (by the blefiing of God, and your Majeftie’s moft gracious protection and favours) do little ooubt but to increase in the further accomplifhment thereof. Ybe tenth Year of Charles I. SefT. 3. CHAP. XV.

A. D. An A& againfl Maintenance* Embracery, &c. and againft «r-1634.	lawful buying of Titles

HR King onr Soveraign Lord, calling to his inoft blefTed remembrance, That there is nothing within this realme that conferveth his loving fubjeds in more quiet-nefle, reft, peace and good concord, then the juft and doe adminiftration of his lawes, and the true and indifferent trials of fuch titles and iflues as be to be tryed according to the lawes of this realme, which his moil royall Majeftie perceiveth to be greatly hindered by maintenance, erabra-ccrv, champerty, fubornation of witnefles, finifter labour, buying of titles and pretended rights of perfons not being in pofteftion, whereupon great perjury hath enfned and much unquietnefie, oppreihon, vexation, trouble, wrongs, and aifinheritance hath followed among his moft loving fob-»ect^, to the great difpleafure of Almighty God, the dif-contentation of his Majeftv, and to the great hinderance and lette of juftice within this his realme ; for the avoyding of all which mifdemeanors, and buying of titles and pretended rights, and to the intent that juftice may be more fully and indifferently miriftered, and the truth in caufes of contention plainly tryed between his fubjeds of.this realm) be it enaded by our Soveraign Lord with the affent of the lords fpirituall and temporal!, and the commons in this prc-l'ent Parliament aflembled, and bv the authority 6f the fame, That from henceforth all ftatutes heretofore made in England concerning maintenance, champerty and embracery, or any of them now Handing and being in their full ftrength and force, shall be put in due execution in this realme of Ireland according to the tenures and efte&s of the fame ftatutes.

il. An A3 concerning Women convided of /mail Felonies.

A. D.	deferving perfons inhabiting or dwelling in England, and

P *634. elfewhere out of this kingdom, titles of honour amongft the nobility of this kingdom of Ireland, whereby they do enjoy place and precidencie according to thofe titles refpe&ive-ly, io it cannot be denied, but that in a juft way of retribution they ought to contribute to all publicke charges and payments taxed by Parliament in this kingdom, from whence the titles of their honors are derived, and where-unto others of ther rank here refident are liable ; be k therefore enadled by the King’s moft excellent Majefty, the lords fpirituall and temporall, and the commons in this pre-fent Parliament aftembled, and by the authority of the fame. An Ad to repeal a Statute, made in the twelfth Yeare of King Edward the Fourth, concerning bringing Bowes into this Realme•

Recital of T T 7HEREAS by an a& of Parliament made in the ta £. 4-a* V V twelfth yeare of King Edward the fourth, entituled. An Ad for bringing Bowes into this realme from the realm of England by met'chants and others ; it is ordained and enadled, «• That every merchant and paflenger, that bring merchandizes into this land of Ireland out of England to thefummeofone hundred pounds, that he fhall buy and bring with him into the faid land in bowes to the value of one hundred fhil-lings, and fo following after the rate under or over to the fumine of twenty pounds; and if any merchant or paflenger bring any merchandize into the faid laid, and bring with him no bowes as is afore rehearfed, that the faid merchant fhall lofe and pay the value of the faid bowes, the one moietie thereof to the King, and the other moiety to the fearchers of the fame for the time being; and that the faid fearchers may have an a&ion of debt againft the faid • perfons therefore in any court that the King hath, as well »for the King as for the faid fearchers ; and that the bailiffes of the cuy of Dublin for the time being be fearchers of the

fame

*8 AT. 4. 1.

An Ad for Repeals of divers Statutes heretofore enacted in this Kingdome of Ireland.

WHEREAS divers ftatutes of force within this king-dome are now by reafon of the bleflcd change of times grown out of ufe, and many of them not fit to be continued, as not forting with the condition of the prefent times, and the happy government under which the fub-jefts of this kingdome doe live ; and that after fo long a quiet among his Majeftie's fubjefts thereof, whofe zeal to his Majeftie's fervice is manifelted upon all occafions, any national diffin&ion or difference between them might prove dangerous : for the abolition of diffin&ion and difference between his Majeftie’s faid dutifull fubjeds of his faid realme of Ireland, and for the perpetuall felling of peace and tranquillity among them, his moft excellent Majefty intending the common and conftant good of his faid realme of Ireland, and of his fubjeds of the fame, and of their pof-terity for ever hereafter, and at the humble defire of his faid fubjeds, is graciouflY pleafed that it may be enaded by his Majefly, and the loros fpirituall and temporal!, and the commons in this prefent Parliament affembled, and be it enaded by the authority of the fame, that one ffatute made in this realme of Ireland, in the five and twentieth year of theraigne of the late King Henry thfc fixth, late King of England and lord of Ireland, whereby it is ordained, “ That he that will be taken for an Englifh man, fhall not ufe a beard upon his upper lippe alone, the offendor fhall be taken as an Irifh enemy and one other ffatute made in the faid realme, in the faid five and twentieth year of the raigne of the faid late King Henry the fixth, whereby it is ordained ** That if an Irilh enemy, received to the King's allegiance, lhall be found after to robbe, fpoyle and ae-ftroy the liege people, it shall be lawfull forx every liege man to doe with him and with his goods, as to a man that never was become litge;” and one other ffatute made in the faid realme in the faid five and twentieth year of the raigne of the faid late King Henry the fixth, againll clipped money, money called O Reylies money, and other un-lawfull money, and againff guilt bridles, peytrells, and other guilt harnyes; and one other ffatute made in the Inid realme, in the eighth and twentieth year of the raigne of the faid late King Henry the Sixth, “ That no mar-chour, nor other man fhall keep more horfemen or footmen then they fhall anfwer for and maintaine upon their own charges, and their tenants, and for prefendng the names of their men; CHAP. X.

An Act tc prevent and punijh the Abnfts in procuring Prbcefle and Supersedeas of the Peace and good Behaviour out of bis Maj fit's Courts of Chancery and King's Bench, and to pre vent Abnfes in procuring Iririts rf Certiorari, &c.

WHEREAS divers turbulent and contentious perfons, fome out of malice, and others in hope of gaine, by way of compofition, do oftentimes upon their corporall oaths, peremptorily and corruptly taken, or otherwife upon felfe fuggeftions and furmiffes, procure precede of the peace or good behaviour out of his Majeftie’s courts of Chancery, and King’s Bench, againff divers of his Majeffie’s quiet fub-je&s, whofe dwellings and aboades are for the moft part in countreyes farre diftant and remote from the faid courts, to their intolerable trouble and vexation, whereas they might, upon good caufe (hewed, receive juft ice at the hands of the Proeefs of juftices of the peace in the counties where they dwell: For peace or good remedy whereof, be it ena&ed by the authority of this pre-chan-enToTb ^Cnt Parliament, That all proceffeof the peace, or good be-R void, unlcli Saviour, after the end of this Parliament to be granted or a* herein. awarded out of the faid courts, or either of them, againff any perfon or perfons whatfoever, at the fuit of, or by the. profecution of any perfon or perfons whatfoever, shall be vcydr, and of none effeft, unleffe fuch proceffe shall be fo granted or awarded upon motion (reft made before the judge or judges of the fame court refpeftively fitting in open court, and upon declaration in writing upon their corporall oaths, to be then exhibited unto them, by the parties which fhall defis e fuch proceffe, of thtcaufes for which fuch pro-

II.	And whereas divers turbulent and contentious perfons, defervedly fearing to be bound to the peace or good behaviour by the juftices of the peace of the counties where they dwell, do oftentimes procure themfelves to be bound to the peace or good behaviour in the faid courts, or one of them, upon infufficierit fureties, or upon colourable profecution of fome perfon or perfons, who will be ready at all times to releafe them at their own pleafure, whereupon his Majcfty’s writs of fuperfedeas are often-times directed to the juftices of* peace, and other his Majefties officers/ requiring them and every of them to forbeare to arreft or imprifon the parties aforefaid, for the caufes aforefaid ; by meanes whereof the faid turbulent and contentious perfons iqifdemeane themfelves amongft their neighbours with impunity, to the great offence and aifturbance of their neighbours amongft whom they converfe and live, and to the affront of the juftices of the peace, and to the evil example and incouragement of like evil difpofed perfons : be it therefore enafted by the authority aforefaid. That all writs of fuperfedeas after the end of SuperfiJctn this prefent Parliament to be granted by or out of either ofalfo void, unlefo the courts aforefaid fhall be voyde and of none effeft, unleffe ^"uTcTicTaf-foch proceffe be granted likewife upon motion in open court fcffcd, and pro-ftrft made as aforefaid, and upon fuch fufEcient fureties as fccutiou is Unm fhall appeare unto the judge or judges of the fame court rc-f<k-fpedtively upon oath, to be affeffedat five pounds lands, or ten pounds in goods in the fubfidie booke at the leaft ; which oathes, and the names of fuch fureties, with the places of their abode, and where they ftand fo affeffed in the fubfidie book, fhall be entred and remaine of record in the fame courts; and unleffe it fhall alfo firft appeare unto the faid judge or judges from whom fuch fuperfedeas is de-fired, that the proceffe of the peace, or good behaviour, is profecuted againft him or them defiring fuch fuperfedeas bona fide, by fome party grieved in that court out of which fuch fuperfedeas is defired to be fo awarded and dire&ed.

An Aft concerning Errors in Records of Attainder of High Treafon and Felonie.

An Act againjt Plowing by the Tayle, and pulling the Wool off living Sheep.

WHEREAS in many Places in this kingdome, there None shall hath been a long time ufed a barbarous cuftome of plow or work ploughing, harrowing, drawing and working with horfes, noi-fesby tha mares, geldings, garrans and colts, by the taile, wherebytai'

(befides the cruelty ufed to the beads) the breed of horfes is much impaired in this kingdome, to the great prejudice thereof; and whereas alfo divers have and yet do ufe the *'a prejudice like barbarous cuftome of pulling off the wooll yearly from to the breed from living fhet p inftcad of clipping or (heering of them ;of horfes. be it therefore enafted by the King’s moil excellent Majeffy, and the lords fpirituall and temporal 1, and the commons in this prefent Parliament affemblcd, that no perfon or perfons whatfoever, shall after one yeare next enfuing the end of

CHAP. XVI.

An Ad for the Supprejfing of Cojberers and Idle Wanderers.

Inconveni-	TT THERE AS there are many young gentlemen of this

wices from co-	y y kingdome that have little or nothing to live on of

*c*	their owne, and will not apply themfelves to labour, or

other honeft induftrious cpurles to fupport themfelves, but doe live idely and inordinately, colhering upon the country* and feffing themfelves, their followers, their horfes and their gray-hounds upon the poore inhabitants, fometimes exading money from them, to fpare them and their tenants, and to

foe elfewhere to their eaught and edraugh, viz. fupperand reakfaft, and fometimes craving helps from them; all which the poore people dare not deny them, fometimes for fhame, but moft commonly for fear of mifehief to be done or procured them fo refufing, and therefore doe bare it although unwillingly, and many times when they are fcarce able To to doe, and yet. dare not complaine for feare of die inconveniencies aforefaid, and to that end doe make cuts, levies and plotments upon themfelves to pay them, and give fuch entertainment and helps to the utter impoverifh-ing and difablinge of the poore inhabitants to pay their duties to the King’s Majeftie, and their rents Unto their landlords ; and by that lawlefle kind of life of thefe idle gentlemen and others, being commonly active young men, and fuch as feek to have itiany followers and dependants upon them, many other inconveniences are likely to arife, for they are apt upon the leaft occafion of difturbance or in-furreflion, to rifle and make bootie of his Majefties loyal! fubjedts, and to be heads and leaders of out-lawes and rebels.

tenth and eleventh Tears of Charles I. CHAP. XVII.

3°4 A. D. *634-35-

An Act to Prevent the unprofitable Cuftom of Burning of Corat in the Straw.

WHEREAS there is in the remote parts of this king-dome of Ireland, commonly a great dearth of cattell yearely, which for the moft part happeneth by reaion of the ill hufbandrie and improvident care of the owners, that neither provide fodder, nor (lover for them in winter, nor houfes to pat them in extremitie of llormy cold weather, bot a naturall lazie difpofition poffeffing them, that will not build bames to houfe and threfh their corn in, or houfes to keep their cattell from the violence pf fuch weather, bot the better to enable them to be flitting from their lands, and to deceive his Majeflie of fuch debts as they may be owing at any time, and their land-lords of their rents, doe for a great part in (lead of threlhing burn their corn in the draw, thereby confuming the draw, which might relieve their cattell in winter, and afford materials towards the covering or thatching their houfes, and fpoiling the corne, making it black, loathfome and filthy; for prevention of which unprofitable and uncivill cuftomes, be it ena&ed by the King's moft excellent Mnjeftie, his lords fpirituall and temporall, and the commons in this prefent Parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame, that no manner of perfon or perfons wharfoever, after fix months next after the end of this fef-fion of Parliament, doe, or shall by himfelfe, wife, children or fervants, tenants or any of them, bume, or caufe Penalty, for to be burned, any corne or graine in the draw, of what firft offence;

Second offence ;

Tlijrd.

Jufticesto commit offenders.

kinde foever, upon pain of imprifonment in the common goale of the county wherein the offence shall be committed, for the fpace of ten dayes, without baile or mainprife, for the firft offence, and the delinquent to pay the charge of fending him or them to the goale as aforefaid, before he or they be thence enlarged ; and for the fecond offence, to be imprifoned by the fpace of one whole month, without baile or mainprife, and to pay the charges as aforefaid ; and for the third offence, to forfeit forty (hillings, and to be bound unto the good behaviour, and to pay the charges as aforefaid, the laid forty (hillings to be paid towards the relief of the prifoners in the faid goale, and to be payed unto the hands of the mayor or chief magiftrate of the place where fuch goale is, or fhall be, (before the offendor be difeharg-ed,) and at his diferetion to be diftributed; and that it shall and may be Iawfull to and for the juftices of the peace of the coumie wher e fuch offences shall be commited, in their feflions of ih e peace, to enquire, hear, and determine,

An ASl for abridging of Proclamations upon Fines, to be le vied at the Common Law.

WHEREAS a ftatute made within the kingdom of Recitrlof4 ?

VI. An A3 concerning Clergy•

jfn far Remedy of Errors and Defers in Fines and Com-soon Recoveries heretofore levied, acknowledged and /offered*

CHAP. I.

An A3 for a Perpetual Anniverfary Tkankjgi<ving on the Nine and Twentieth Dap of May in this Kingdom.

Preamble. T^i ORASMUCH as Almighty God the King of Kings, £/ and foie difpofer of all earthly crowns and kingdoms, * hath by his afwaying providence and power, miraculoofly demonftrated in the view of all the world his tranfeendant mercy, love and goodnefs towards his mod excellent Ma-jefty Charles the fecond, by his efpecial grace, of England, . Scotland, France and Ireland King, defender of the truely ancient catholique and apoftolique faith, and all his Majesties loyal fubje&s of this his kingdom of Ireland, by his Majedies late mod wonderful, glorious, peaceable and joyful redauration to the a&ual pofleffion and exercize of his undoubted hereditary foveraign and regal authority over us, after fundry years forced extermination into foraign parts by the mod trayterous confpiracies, and armed power of ufurping tyrants, and execrable perfidious traytors 5 and that without the lead oppofition or effufion of^blood, through the unanimous, cordial, loyal votes, and paffionate defires of us, and other his Majedies fubjeds; which unexpreffible blefLng, by God’s own mod wonderful difpenfation, was tyth of May, compleated on the nine and twentieth day of May, one KingVbirth thoufand fix hundred and fixty, being the mod memorable and red oration. bjrth-daf1101 onely of his Majedy as a man, and a prince, but likewife as an a&ual King; and to this and other his Majedies kingdoms, in a manner new bom, and railed from the dead on this mod joyful day: in confideration whereof, this being the day which the Lord himfelf had made, and crowned with fo many publick bleflings and fignal deliverances both of his Majedie and his people, from all their late mod deplorable confufions, divifions, wan, defoliations and oppreifions; to the end that it. may be kept

An Atl for the better Execution of His Majefties gracious Declaration for the Settlement of his Kingdom of Ireland, and Satisfaction of the federal Intercjls of Adventurers, Souldiers and other bis Subjects there.

WHEREAS an unnatural infurredion did break forth againft your Majefties royal Father of ever bleifed m cm one, bis crown and dignitie, in this your Majefties kingdom of Ireland upon the 23. of Odober, in the year of our Lord God 1641, and manifeft itfelfbythe murther and deftrudions of many thousands of your faid Majefties good and loyal fubjeds; which afterwards univedaily Spreading and diffuftng itfelf over the whole kingdom, fettled into, and became a formed and allmoft national rebellion of the Irilh pa pills, again ft your royal father of blefled memorie, his ctown and dignitie, to the deftruetion of the Englilh and proteftants inhabiting in Ireland, the which Irilh papifts being reprefented in a general afTemWy chofen by themfelves, and a&ing by a council called by them, “ The fupreme council of the confederate Roman Catholicks of Ireland,” did iirft affume, ufurp and exercife the power of life and death, make peace and war, levie and coin money, and many other ads of foveraign audio-thoritie, treating with for reign princes and potentates for their government and protedkm, and afterwards aded under a forreign authoritie, by all the faid ways disowning and rejecting your royal father, and your Majefties undoubted right to this kingdom, even whileft they trcach-eroufly ufed his and your Majefties names in the outward forms of their proceedings, withall impioufly feeming by words and Shows to fwear even unto that, which by the whole feries of their deeds they denied ; and moreover prefuming to pretend his late Majefties moft facred authorise, even for their worft adions all whi6h they did (amongft other their evil defigns) to frighten his good pro-teftant fubjeds from their loyaltie, to blaft his Majefties honour, and to widen the breach between his faid Majcftie and his feduced fubjeds in England ; the which ends, by their hiid wicked ftratagems, they did too fuccefsfully and mifehievoufly effed : and whereas Almightie God hath given yourMajeftie, by and through your faid F.nglifh and proteftant fubjeds, absolute vidorie and conqueft over the faid Irilh popilh rebels and enemies, fo as they, their lives, liberties and eftates are now wholly at your Majefties difpo-fttion by the laws of this kingdom : and whereas feveral of your Majefties fubjeds, by whom, as inftruments, the faid rebels were totally fubdued, did in the time of your

It having pleafed Almighty God out of his great mercy 1662. and companion towards us, and all our fubje&s, to reftore Chap. 2. us in fo wonderful a manner to each other, and with fo wonderful circumllances of affe&ion and confidence in each other as mull for ever fill our hearts (if we are in any degree fenfible of fuch bleffings) with an humble and grate-full acknowledgment of the obligation we owe to his Divine Providence, that he would vouchfafe to work that miracle for us himfelf, which no endeavours of our own could bring to pafs: We think it agreeable to the juft fenfe we have, and ought to have of the good affe&ion of all our good fubje&s, who have contributed fo much in bringing this unspeakable bleffing upon us and themfelves, that we acknowledge that our good fubje&s in our king-dome of Ireland have born a very good part in procuring this happinefs, that they were early in their dutifall ad-dreffes to us, and made the fame profeffions of refolution to return to their duty and obedience to us, during the time of our being beyond the Teas, which they ha^e fince fo eminently made good and put in pradlice; however it was not cafy for us to make any publick declaration with reference to that our kingdome, there being many difficulties in the providing for, and complying with the feveral interefts ana pretences there, which we were bound in honour and juftice in fome degree to take care of, and which were different from the difficulties we were to contend within this kingdom : we well knew the adls of Parliament which had formerly pad for the fecurity of the adventurers in that kingdom, and had heard of the proceedings which had been thereupon, by which very many officers, fouldiers, and others, as well of this, as that our kingdome were in poffcffion of a great part of the lands of that our kingdom, and of whofe interefts we refolve to be very careful.

II. We well remember the ceffation, and the peace which our royal father of bleffed memorie had been forced, during the late troubles, to make with the Irifh fubje&s of that our kingdom, and by which he was compelled to give them a full pardon fer what they had before done amifs upon their return to their dutie, and their promife of giving his Majeftje a vigorous affiftance, and that from that time divers perfons of honour and qualitie had not (that we know or have heard of) fwerved from their allegiance towards him or us. We could not forget the peace that ourfelf was afterwards neceffitated to make with our faid fubjetts, in the time when they who wickedly ufurped the authorise in this kingdom, had erefted that odious court for the taking away of the life of our dear father; and . then no bodie can wonder that wc were defirous, though

V. XXVIII.	And though feme, not fenfible of the great perplexities we have laboured under to reconcile thefe jarring intcrells, may ihfer. jin A3 for making all Hofilers, Inholders and others, anfwer-able for fuch Horfes, Geldings or Mares as they jbad take upon them the Charge and Keeping of, in Stables or Out-grounds.

WHEREAS hoftlers, inholders, and others who take Hoftlers, In-upon themfelves to keep inns or llables, or both, holders, &c. an* ^.nd out-grounds for grafing of horfes, are many times very j^^#bdc[°yCfCC negligent in keeping fuch horfes as are committed to their ™beker** charge, and much the more negligent, becaufe it is conceived that they are not anfwerable for any horfes which are turned by them to grafs, as for thofe which they keep within ftables; whereby many gentlemen and others are jnany times difappointed of their horfes, and often do lofe them upon pretence of Health and the like, whereas fometimes they are conveyed away by the pra&ice and privity of thofe who are intrufted with the keeping of tjiem ; may it therefore pleafe your Majefty that it be enabled, and be it enabled by your Majefty, with the aflent and confent of the lords fpiritual and temporal, and commons in Parliament afiembled, that all and every hoftler, inholder or others, who do or shall at any time hereafter take upon them the charge and keeping of horfes, geldings or mares in ftables or out-grounds, shall be henceforth anfwerable for fuch horfes, geldings or mares which fliall be delivered to them to be kept; any law, cuftom pr ufage heretofore to the contrary notwithftanding.

That the faid office or offices in all places where they shall be appointed shall be kept open all dayes, except the Lord's day or holy dayes, in all places from nine of the clock to twelve in the forenoon, and from two of the dock til! five in the afternoon of each day, for the taking and inregillring the entries of all merchants, retailers, brewers and others, and for the receiving all monies which ihall be due and payable by all or any of them, and for other things necefiary to be done, touching the bufinefs of excife, aid the affairs relating thereunto.
