XVII.	Provided alfo, that this aft, or any thing therein contained, shall not extend to charge any perion or perfons with any penalty or forfeiture for or concerning any matter or thing done contrary to the tenour of this aft, or any part thereof, unlcfs the party or parties offending, shall be lued or profecuted for the fame within twelve months after fuch matter cr thing shall be done and committed as afore-laid ; any thing in this aft, or any other law, cuftom or nfage whatfoever to the contrary notwith(landing.

XVIII.	And becaufe by experience it is found, that the hindering of merchants ftrangers and others from vending his or their goods without offering them firft to fome bur-gefs or freeman of fuch city, corporation or town, where fuch merchant ftranger or other, do arrive with his or their goods, (commonly Known by the name of town-bargain) is very deftruftive to the trade and commerce of this realm, and very prejudicial to your Majeftie’s revenue; be it therefore enafted by the authority aforefaid, That from and after the faid ilrft day of December one thoufand fix hundred fixty oru , no fuch town-bargain shall be required, nor any merchant or other hindered or withheld from dif-pofing of his or th^ir goods, wares or merchandifes, without

Importer*may offering them as aforefaid ; but that all and every merchant difpofe of their ftranger or other importing any goods,wares or merchandifes nodsat plea- from beyond the Teas, and paying all duties by law due and m»	payable	thereupon,	(hall	and may from time to time, and

at all times, at his and their will and pleafurc, freely and without lett, moleftation or hinderance, fell and difpofe of his or their goods and merchandifes; any charter, cuftom, nfage, priviledge or liberty of or unto any city or town corporate, at any time made, given, granted, to the contrary in any wife not with Handing.

Abufeoftown XIX. And forafmuch as feveral ancient duties under the «*d petty name of town and petty cuftoms, due and payable bv merchants (hangers unto (everal cities and towns corporate of this your Majeftie’s realm, have been and are demanded, received and taken by their farmers, deputies or officers, in a fur greater quantity and proportion than is of right belonging, in refpeft the fame have been, and are tequired upon more goods than are truly liable thereunto, and according to the rates after which the cuftoms have been from time to time increafed, and paid unto your Majefty, and your royal predeceffors, which exceed far the ancient rates, according to which fuch petty cuftoms can be required and taken; be it further enafted and ordained by the authority aforefaid, That from henceforth no fuch c^d* petty cuftoms be demanded, received or paid, for or upon «nodme«not" ***7 morc or 0ther commodities than were chargeable with

XX.	And if there shall happen to be brought in or car- Goods not ried out of this realm any goods liable to the payment of c adorn and fubfidie, which either are not mentioned in this ^a|] the’ book, or are not now ufed to be brought in or carried out, Cuftom accord-or by reafon of the great diverfity of the value of fome in* to the true goods could not be rated, that in fuch cafe every cufiomer or value, affirmed collector for the time being shall levy the faid cuflom and ™ 1^ fubfidie of poundage, according to the true value and price of fuch goods, to be affirmed upon the oath of the merchant in the prefence of the cufiomer, colie&or, comptroller and furveyor, or any two of them.

* Repealed.

f Repealed, as to Duty on Bay-Yam.

Certain

fir fourteenth andfifteenth Tears ef Charles IT*

Certain Rules, Orders, and Directions for the Advancement of Trade and Encouragement of Merchant', as afo for regulating as vjcil of the Merchants, in making of due Entries, and juft Payments of their Cufioms, as of the Officers in all the Ports of this Realm, in the Receipts of their frvcral Fees, and tn the faithful Management of their Duties and Trufis*

*

VERY merchant shall have free liberty to break bulk

in any port allowed by the law, and to pay cuftom and fubfidy for no more than he fhall enter and land ; provided that the matter or purfer of every (hip shall firtt make declaration upon oath, before any two principal officers, of the true content of his (hips lading, and shall likewife after declare upon his oath, before the cuttomer, colle&or, comptroller or furveyor, or two of them, at the next port of this realm where his (hip shall arrive, the quantity and qua-lity of goods landed at the other port where bulk was broken, and to whom they did belong.

II.	No merchant, native or ftranger, shall (hip off the goods of a ftranger in the name of a native, upon pain of forfeiture and k>oling the goods and merchandifes fo entred, and ail his goods perfonal.

III.	Every merchant born out of the dominions of his Majeftv, and after made denizen, shall pay the cuf-tom as before he was made denizen, unlef> he do inhabit and be conftantly abiding or dwelling in fome part or place of this realm ; in that cafe, fuch merchants shall pay only as a natural born fubjeft, and not other-wife.

IV.	All fugar* and other foreign goods and merchan-difes (except wines, tobacco, wrought filks, haberdaffiery, and all forts of grocery wares) firtt imported, shall be again exported by any merchant who is a fubjefl of this realm, or any other his Majefties dominions, within twelve months, or ftranger within nine months; and fuch merchant or merchants as shall export any fuch foreign goods or merchandifes (except before excepted) tha'l have allowance, and be repaid by the officer which received the fame, the one moyety of the cuftom or fubfidy which was paid at the firtt importation of fuch foreign goods and merchandifes, or any part thereof; and fo as due proof be firtt made by certificate from the officers of their due entry and payment of the cuftom and fubfidy of all fuch foreign goods and merchandifes inwards, together with the further oath of die merchants importing and exporting the fame, affirming the truth thereof, and the name of his Majefties fearcher or under-fearcher in the port of Dublin, and of the fearcher p{ lyy other the ports, teftifying the (hipping thereof to be

4	exported	s



The fourteenth andfifteenth Tears of Charles II.	569

exported; after all which duely performed in manner be- A. D. fore exprefled, the movety of the fubfidy firft paid inwards	166a.

(hail without any delav or reward, more than the duty fet Chap. 9. down in the table of fees for the certificate, be repaid ^ unto fuch merchant or merchants who do export fnch goods and merchandises, within one month after demand thereof.

V.	If any merchant having duely paid all duties inwards for foreign goods, and in regard of fales had, shall be enforced to keep th^ fame or any part thereof in his hands, without alteration of the property, after the fpace of a year shall be elapfed; in this cafe, he is to be permitted to (hip the fame out for any the ports beyond the feas (if he fo think fit) without payment of any fubfidy for the fame outwards, upon due proof that the fame was duely entered, and fubfidy paid inwards.

VI.	No merchant or other perfon whatfoever shall have any allowance or abatement of fubfidy made him by bill of dore or otherwife, for any fort of tobacco, under pretence df being corrupt or unmerchantable; but in cafe any merchant shall refufe to make entry of fuch tobacco, and to par the full fubfidy of the fame, the principal officers of the col-tom-houfe, or any two of them, shall diufe all fuch corrupt tobacco to be publickly burnt, as not wholefome for ufe, and the owner thereof is to be difeharged from paying any fubfidy for the fame.

VII.	Every merchant bringing in any forts of wines into this realm by way of merchandise, and making due entries of the fame in the cuftom-houfe, shall be allowed ten per centum for leakage, to be taken or deducted not out of the quantities of wines, but out of the monies received for the fiibfidy ; provided fuch wines be not filled up on (hip-board, and if fo, no allowance then to be made at all for the fame.

. VIU. Every merchant shall be allowed npon all other goods and merchandises appointed to pay the fubfidy of poundage according to the rule of the before going book of rates to be imported, five in the hundred of all the faid fob-*

(idles of poundage fo appointed to be paid.

IX.	Every hogfhead of wine which shall be run out, and not full feven inches or above left therein, and every butt or pipe not above nine inches, shall be accounted for outs, and ttie merchant to pay no fubfidy for tbe fame.

Chap. 9. XI. If any goods or merchandises, except tobacco, Vbrought into this kingdom, shall receive any damage by fait water or otherwife, fo that the owner thereof shall be prejudiced in the fale of fuch goods; the commiffioners in the port cf Dublin, and the principal officers of the cuftom-houfe in all other the ports, or any two of them, whereof the collector for the time being to be one, shall have power to choofe two indifferent merchants experienced in the values of fuch goods, who upon vifiting of tne (aid goods shall cer-tifie and declare upon their corporal oaths, firft adminiftered by the fatd coxnmiffioners or officers, what damage fuch goods have received and are leflened in their true value, and according to fuch damage in relation to the rates fet on them in the foregoing book of rates the faid officers are to make a proportionable abatement onto the merchant or bwner of the fubfidy due for the fame.

XII. All merchants tranfportmg any (ort of woollen cloth called old drapery, as alfo bayes and cottons, shall be allowed one in ten for a wrapper, free of cuftom and fubfidy.

XUI. Inafmuch as the natural fit nation of this realm renders it fufficiently convenient for the floring and laying up of commodities and merchandise brought in with intent to be afterwards carried out again for Tupply of foreign markets, by which much benefit and advantage may anfe to his Majeflie and people; the lord deputy therefore, or other chief govemour or governours and privy council of this realm for the time being, shall and may (as they in their judgments shall feem meet, and find mod advantageous ana beneficial to his Majeftie and this kingdom) appoint one certain port in each province of this realm, to which all merchants Grangers and their fadors, fending his or their goods, with intent and to the end and porpofe afore-(aid, may upon a reafonable compofition or agreement, to be agreed on by direction of the (aid lord deputy, or other chief govemour or governours and privy council aforefaid, and payment thereof made unto the colledor or collectors df thole ports, in lieu of all cuftoms or fubfidies due and payable by this prefent ad, there land and lay the fame up in his Majeftie’s ware-houfe at the cuftom-honfe of thole places, or fuch other ware-houfes or places, and no other, as shall be provided for that end and purpofeby the colledor, cuftomer and fcarcher of thofe ports, under whole joint cuftody the fame are to remain until they be (hipped out again,* which shall be done again without payment of any duties outwards, or any thing more than a reafonable rate for warehoufe room; but if any merchant, fador, or other

XIV.	The officers who fit above in the cuftom-houfe of the port of Dublin, shall attend the fervice of their feverala.6. places from nine to twelve of the clock in the forenoon, and nC<13* one officer pr one able clerk shall attend with the book in

XV.	The fearcher, furveyor, or other officer attending in any port or creek, shall give knowledge to the colle&or of the head port to which they belong, with all convenient fpeed, of every (hip that cometh in or goeth out at any tide, by way of merchandife, or with goods from another port by way of certificate.

XVI.	There shall be one (hippers book outwards, and another inwards, kept in every cuftom houfe, wherein every (hip or veflel going out or coming in by way of merchandife, or with commodities of this kingdom to or from any other ports by certificate, shall enter openly in the cuftom-houfe the name of the (hip and of the mailer, the burthen, from whence, and to and from what place it is freighted, before he take in any lading or difcharge any goods, wares Or merchandifes whatfoever.

XVII.	The mailer or purfer of every (hip coming in by way of merchandife, shall deliver under his hand, and upon his oath before the colle&or or cheque, one bill of the particulars and contents of the whole lading of the (hip, with the names of the feveral merchants, and the mark, pack, or outward form of the goods and merchandifes, according to his knowledge, and shall alfo make declaration thereof upon oath.

XVIII.	Every matter of a (hip, that shall lade any goods or merchandifes for any parts bcybnd the Teas, shall enter his fhip with the colle&or and cheque, before he take in any goods, and before his departure shall give notice of his whole lading, with the names of the merchants that have laden goods in him, and shall anfwer upon oath to fuch quettions concerning the fame, as shall be demanded of him.

XIX.	No entry nor agreement with any merchant or others for cuttoms or fubfidy shall be made by the colle&or or others, nor any cocquet, warrant, or certificate fealed or fubfcribed, but openly in the cuftom houfe.

XX.	Every merchant making an entry of goods, either inwards or outwards, shall be aifpatched in Inch order as he cometh ; and if any officer or his clerk shall either for favourer reward put any merchant or his fervant duly attending by his turn, or otherwift delay any perfon fo duly attending and making his entries aforefaid, to draw any other reward or gratqity from him than is limited in the table of fees hereafter following; if the matter, officer, or the clerk be found faulty therein, they shall refpe£lively? upon complaint to the faid commiffionert or chief officers, be publickly difeharged of their refpedive ira-ployments, and not permitted to fit any more in the cuftom-houfe.

XXXV.	Every officer that maketh any cocquet or warrant contrary or disagreeing to the entry of any goods or merchandizes shall lofe his or their place.

For every pack of yarn, fardle, or bag of wool, (kins, and all other packable commodities, packer four pence.

7*bt fourteenth andfifteenth Years of Charles II. CHAP. XVII.

A. D. 1662.

An A3 for eflabli/bing em additional Revenue upon bis Ma-jejiy, bis Heirs and Succ effort, for the better Support of bis and their Crown and Dignity.

FORASMUCH as nothing conduceth more to the peace and profperity of a kingdom, and the protection of every (ingle perfon therein, than that the publick revenue thereof may be in fome meafure proportioned to the publick charges and expences; in confederation thereof, and to the intent and purpofe that his Majefty, his heirs and fucceflors may receive a full and ample recom-pence and fatisfadion for the profits of the court of wards in this kingdom, and the tenures, wardfhips, liber* ties, primer feizint, Oufier lemains, values and forfeitures of marriage, by rcafon of any tenure of the King’s Mar jelly, or of any other by knights fervice, and all mean rates, and all other gifts, grants, charges incident or arif-ing for or by rcafon of the fame and other perquifites incident thereunto, and for all arrears, accompts and demands any way due or payable for or by reafon of the fame from any of his Majefties fubjeds of this his kingdom of Ireland, fince the three and twentieth of O&ober, one thou-fand fix hundred forty and one, or that may grow due hereafter$ be it enabled and it is enaded by the King’s moft excellent Majefty, by and with the advice and confent of the lords fpiritual and temporal and commons in this pre-fent Parliament alfembled, and by the authority of the Altered by fame. That for the confiderations aforefaid from and after 33 G. 3. C. 14. the twenty ninth day of September, in the year of our Lord God one thoufand fix hundred fixty two, every dwelling and other houfe and edifice that are or hereafter shall be ereded within this kingdom of Ireland, other than fuch as in this ad are hereafter excepted, shall be chargeable, and by this prefent ad be and are charged with the annual payment to the King’s Majefiy, his neirs and fucceflors for every fire hearth, and other place ufed for firing and ftoves within every fuch houfe and edifice as aforefaid, the fum of two (hillings fieri, by the year, to be paid yearly and every year at the feafi of the annuntiadon of the Blefled Virgin St. MARY, and the feafi of St. MICHAEL the arch-angel, by even and equal portions ; the firft payment thereof to be paid upon the feafi day of the annua-ciation of the Blefled Virgin St. MARY, which ihall be in the year of our Lord one thoufand fix hundred fixty three.

' CHAP. XVIII.

An At7 for tf e improvement of bit Maje/Ue*s Revenues upon the granting of Licences for the felltng of ale and Beer.

'ORASMUCH as it is found bv daily experience. That many mifchlefs and inconveniencies do arife from the exceflive number of ale-houfes, by the ere&ion of them in woods, bogs, and other unfit places, and many of them not in townftrips, but difperfcdly, and in dangerous places, and kept by unknown perfons not undertaken for, wnereby many times they become receptacles for rebels,' and other malefadors, and harbours for gamefters, and other idle, disordered and unprofitable livers, and that thofc that keep thofe ale-houfes, for the mod part are not fitted or furnifh-ed to lodge or entertain travellers in any decent manner; for the redrefs of thofe inconveniencies, and many other mifehiefs daily obferved to grow by the courfe now held, and to reduce needlefs multitudes, of ale-bouies to a fewer number, to more fit perfons, and more convenient places; be it enabled by the King’s mod excellent Majefty, with the advice of the lords fpiritual and temporal and commons in this prefent Parliament a (Tern bled, and by the authority of the fame, that no manner of perfon whatfoever, (halt keep any aie-houfe, or tinling-houfe, nor fell any ale or beer by retail within this kingdom, but onely fuch as fhaU be licenced according to the true meaning of this aSt, and upon fuch pain as herein after is exprelfcd, (that is to fay) that every perfon, which shall be licenfed to fell ale or beer, fhall upon receipt of his licenfe pay to his Ma-jelty twenty (hillings current money of and ip England, for every year that he Ihall Hand or be fo licenfed to fell the fame.

II. And for that no licences can be granted but by fome perfons to be fufficicntly authorized ; it is therefore enacted, that commifiions ihall from time to time be awarded under his Maje(lie’s great fcal, unto every county, city and town corporate within this kingdom to a convenient number of commiflioners, fome of the chief to be of the /«»-rum, to be nominated by the chief governour or governours of this kingdom, with the con fen c of tne council for the time being, the faid commiflioners to bechofen of the juf-tices of the peace, with others »o be added to them, in every county of this kingdom, as the chief governour or governours and council of this kingdom for the time being jnall think fit ; which commiflioners shall confider as well of the number fit to be allowed to keep alc-houfes, as of the places where the fame lhail be kept, and of die ability

That the? twenty-third day of O&cber shall be kept and celebrated as an anniverfary holy day in this kingdom for ever, and that all perfons do at that day forbeare all bodily labour, and tne exercife of their trades; and that all and fingular mini fieri in every cathedral and parifh church, or other ufual place for common-prayer within this realm of Ireland, shall always opon the twenty-third day of O&ober fay morning-prayer, and give thanks to Almighty God for that moil happy and miraculous deliverance and prefervation far above the expectations of thofe wretched confpirators ; and that all and every perfon and perfons inhabiting within thin realm of Ireland (ball yearly, upon the twenty-third day of Odlober, diligently and faithfully refort to the parifh church or chappcl accuftomed, or to fome ufual church or chappel where the faid morning-prayer, preaching, or other fervice of God shall be ufed, and then ami there abide orderly and foberly during the time of tbs faid prayers, preaching or other fervice of God there to be ufed and miniftered.

II. And becaufe all and every perfon may be put in mind of his duty, and be then the better prepared to the faid holy fervice ; be it ena&ed by the authority afore faid. That every minifter shall give warning to his parifhioners publickly in the church at morning-prayer, the Lords day next before every fuch twenty-third of Odober, for the due obfervation of the faid day; and that after morning-prayer or preaching upon every fuch twenty-third of Odober they read publickly, diftindly, and plainly this prefent ad.
